Author: seanlinehan
Content:
Slack and Dropbox have pretty different business models from my vantage point. Slack entered the market as an enterprise product vs. consumer. Slack was built for collaboration from day 1, so there is some amount of lock in (change management in an organization is tough).

I look at Slack as being more like a hybrid of the best parts of Box + Dropbox... They have the good parts of Box's business model and the UX quality of Dropbox. And fortunately for them, they aren't in a market where the price is driven largely by the cost of the commodity hardware underneath them.

Author: glial
Content:
> Don't big alarm bells go off in your head when you hear N parameters for N data points?

Gaussian process models typically also have hyperparameters that control things like the smoothness of the learned surface. My hand-wavey sense of how GPs work is that you have a prior distribution over functions (think curves) and a hyperparameter controlling the smoothness/length-scale of those functions. You observe data, then find the posterior distribution over functions that make your data most likely - i.e. of all these possible functions, which ones have the best chance of actually generating the data you're observing? The shape of that posterior distribution depends on the set of N points you observe, and it will be different if you have different data. In that sense, then, the data are parameters, since the posterior depends exactly on the set of data.

The analogy to traditional regression comes by having the hyperparameters (controlling the covariance function IIRC, i.e. the smoothness of the posterior curves), which allows the resulting posterior distribution to explain the data perfectly (overfitting, sharp curves) or not (generalizability, smooth curves). See for example slides 23-24 of this slide deck:

https://www.cs.toronto.edu/~hinton/csc2515/notes/gp_slides_f...

Rasmussen has some useful video tutorials of all this. It's been a few years since I've watched them but if you're interested I'd recommend them.

Author: Blueliner
Content: Stripe ACH service has been in "beta" for at least two years. I contacted them that long ago and was told it would be available by the end of 2014 and it is still in "beta" and not generally available. As the co-founder of an enterprise SaaS app startup where our average per use charge for a customer to use our app (we charge on a per use basis not straight subscription) starts in the hundreds of dollars and can run into the thousands paying the standard 2.9% + credit card fees for every payment vs. $.10 - $.50 max for an ACH charge is a complete non-starter for us and our customers. All of Stripe's competitors have had ACH forever including Balanced who we talked to but Stripe continues to drag its feet and not provide ACH. Clearly it isn't for technical reasons but because they make significantly more revenue and profit by not offering ACH where their transaction fee is much less. So while I respect what Stripe did early on to make integrating payments into an app much easier than the previous generation payment providers requiring a lot of up front fees, merchant accounts, etc. we will never consider them again unless and until they offer ACH and I'm sure there are lots of other enterprise app companies who won't use them either without ACH because customers demand it vs. having to run up huge monthly charges on their company credit cards. Too bad that Stripe management is proven to put their profits (and greed) ahead of providing cost effective solutions for their customers.

Author: shmerl
Content:
> But streaming isn't convenience

For me it's convenience.

> At no point do you buy any albums, you merely rent them while you listen to them.

I don't really understand the concept of renting for digital goods. Since they can be duplicated practically at no cost, there is no practical reason to "take and return" approach (i.e. rent). Keeping your digital copy does not reduce any value for the service.

> Otherwise you could subscribe for one month and download every single piece of music you can within 30 days, then cancel

That can easily be prevented by saying that you can't exceed certain limit of downloads for such service if you only pay per month, and not for each copy. But again, I see no reason why they can't offer an option to pay per copy and let you keep one.

Author: cryoshon
Content:
I would also highly suggest Giere's book, Understanding Scientific Reasoning: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/015506326X/ref=as_li_tl?ie=...

It's a textbook so it's a bit denser than a standard nonfiction offering, but it explains the perspectives of a few famous philosophers of science, the scientific method, clears up some common misunderstandings, and is packed with case studies which make the concepts easy to understand. It's a great piece for either reference or learning about science in general.

Author: partiallypro
Content:
VC-backed firms that are focused on enterprise don't worry me, those focused on the consumer side worry me. Consumers are more fickle than businesses, which generally lock in vendors and want streamlined items.

With consumers, an item like Snapchat is the hot item today, but AIM was the hot item before that, then it was Skype, etc, etc, etc. Consumers don't have the loyalties that enterprise has. Facebook was smart because it has built an ecosystem around its graph, others haven't and I fear eventually those "utlra-unicorns" are going to face reality and that is going to hurt firms, even your own.

And with some firms their path to profitability is total nonsensical. Monetizing is extremely difficult when you can't actually charge your customers in any significant way without completely driving them away.

Author: makecheck
Content:
Well, I wholeheartedly agree that the current Skype is in that category. Sadly, that is only because it has become that way. It used to be nearly the opposite, a great example of what chat could be.

Very early versions of the Mac Skype client (like 2.x or so) had a completely different UI layout that was multi-window and multitasking, and the program worked absurdly better back then.

Around version 5.x they started making mind-bogglingly stupid UI changes and I stubbornly held onto an old 2.x client just so I could keep the interface that was actually sensible.

So then, what does Microsoft do? They start screwing with the protocol itself and making everything refuse to work at all unless it is running the latest version. Then they introduce more ads and a generally scummier experience from one release to the next.

Even all of that was almost tolerable. Then they made a major "update" to the iOS client that must have removed about 50% of Skype's features for no apparent reason, and added annoyances or random breakages to whatever was left. Fortunately though, the release notes made it clear that they had flattened some buttons so we could all feel good about Skype's usefulness having been mostly obliterated.

Microsoft has, quite simply, ruined Skype. There is no more suitable word than that. It was a very promising protocol and the clients worked well, and Microsoft just completely destroyed it. It's honestly hard to believe the team is being paid to enhance Skype because it really does seem that the team is instead being given instructions to damage Skype in any way possible.

Author: grover_hartmann
Content:
Not really, it depends.

You don't need a bank account to accept bitcoins, all you need is a Bitcoin wallet.

If what you want is to convert bitcoin to fiat currency, there are lots of ways to do that.

You can do that by using Circle/Coinbase and link your accounts to a bank account, have Coinbase/Circle convert it to cash for you.

Other ways to do that is with an ATM, bitcoin credit/debit cards, localbitcoins.com, etc.

I suggest Bitcoin because it's been way more flexible and easier for me when it comes to international payments.

Good luck.

Author: somberi
Content:
Some friendly suggestions:

1. The domain name could be different. It is a little longwinded and it does not convey the value of the service clearly. It places it in a SOS context, whereas you will be able appeal to a larger customer base if it were positioned as a Chef-on-tap service.

2. How do you throttle chatty customers? How do you rebate non-power-users?

3. $20 per month is on a high side (I can get A family plan of Google Music and Netflix for ~3$ more per month). I am not saying everything should be pegged to these services, but as a customer I think this way. May be charge per question?

4. How have you implemented the chat? Curious to learn.

All the best.

Author: PerfectElement
Content:
There's no typical vegan diet, just like there's no typical non-vegan diet. Vegans can eat whole foods, junk food, high-carb, low-carb, high-protein, etc. There's no macro or micro nutrient that comes exclusively from animals. (Btw, I've never seen Sauerkraut that wasn't vegan.)

I've been vegan for 10 years, have lived in 3 different countries and have met a lot of vegans, usually in situations where food was involved. My personal experience indicates that, overall, vegans eat less processed/refined foods than non-vegans and are more knowledgeable about nutrition than the average.

Author: codingthebeach
Content:
Interesting ah..perspective.

To me, and to most builders, Windows desktops, and OS X / Linux desktops, are far more viable than iOS or Android; not less. Even John Gruber admits that the iOS app store is rotting.

https://daringfireball.net/linked/2015/12/01/sketch-leaves-m...

Desktop machines may not be sexy -- unless you happen to like games, your example of choice -- but they're reliable, users understand them, they exist in huge numbers, and they're never going away, because humans will always like large, high-resolution displays, and whatever computing device provides that will be "the desktop" going forward.

The comment about "infesting Windows PC with viruses and software" is also inaccurate, and has been since about 2008 or so.

Author: avar
Content:
We've eclipsed the usefulness of this birdhouse analogy, but suffice to say being able to replace one proprietary commercial vendor with another doesn't make something open source.

    > This is some kind of confluence of the values of
    > FSF captial-F "Free" style software with the more
    > pragmatic goals associated with open source.
Well, pragmatically, if you needed to alter the hardware of this "open source" hardware what percentage of the total electronic complexity would you be working with? I'm going to aim for a conservative one-digit percentile.

There's a real and unambiguous line to be drawn in the sand here. If you get "open source" plans for hardware that you can't replicate with third-party fabrication & your own materials it's not open source. It's just a recipe for assembling commercial proprietary components.

It's awesome that people publish those recipes, but don't call it open source hardware and dilute the meaning of hardware that is genuinely open.

Author: emcq
Content:
I agree that neuromorphic is often specious, but it's not fair to say that neuromorphic hardware fails if it can do non brain like computations more efficiently than conventional hardware.

The thesis may be misguided at times but building non-traditional hardware that provide significant efficiencies is a wonderful thing. Sometimes it takes a random vector to get off a local maximum.

For example, did you know Synaptics, the guys who developed the touch input you're probably using started as a crazy neuromorphic thing from Carver Mead? [0]

While most of the IBM press is garbage, they do seem to be making progress running conventional DNNs on their hardware, showing backprop in low precision, and suggesting progress on CNNs. [1,2]

[0] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carver_Mead#Touch

[1] https://papers.nips.cc/paper/5862-backpropagation-for-energy...

[2] http://p9.hostingprod.com/@modha.org/blog/2015/12/nips_2015_...

Author: HiLo
Content:
I stopped at "Perhaps the best description of the rigged game HFT’s play comes from the book..."

Just because they aren't guaranteeing your execution price when you trade in larger size blocks doesn't mean the game is rigged. This has been discussed to death. Sure, a few bad apples used the technology for frontrunning, but then we have a frontrunning problem, not an HFT problem.

Furthermore, just like the stat arb strategies of the past that eventually expanded beyond Wall St into everyday retail and online analytics, HFT strategies may be hard to understand but it's not like this is some mafia forcing you to pay a toll to trade... it's far, far more nuanced.

Author: untog
Content:
I see no correlation between streaming (convenience) and forbidding one to download what is streamed (DRM).

But streaming isn't convenience, it's the business model. At no point do you buy any albums, you merely rent them while you listen to them. Otherwise you could subscribe for one month and download every single piece of music you can within 30 days, then cancel. That's pretty obviously not how the system is designed to be used.

I'm not sure what the solution is as I love the internet being open, but a huge proportion of the planet is made up of children and they can go watch ISIS behead someone or a woman shit in the mouth of a man whenever their classmate dares them.

I'd much rather have my children see that and talk to me about it because they trust me rather than not mentioning it because they worked around a web filter (which is inevitable [check out my ubuntu live usb stick, or my ssh tunnel]) and are afraid of getting in trouble.

Author: joepie91_
Content:
People don't read footnotes. If you start out with a list of "OMG warning signs" and then add an "oh, never mind" disclaimer below it, then the average paranoid parent isn't even going to read beyond the last bulletpoint before confronting their kid.

This article is extremely dangerous.

EDIT: And when I say "footnote", I mean that more generically, not just with it being literally below the content. People don't read linearly, and will almost certainly read the bulletpoints before they read the text around it.

Author: emcq
Content:
To be fair, the goal of those new computing architectures is not to advance algorithms. That at best is a side benefit.

Those algorithmic performance improvements seen in DNN have come from improved datasets and training. Numenta and IBM arent focusing on training AFAIK. Google's Quantum Annealing [0] is the only hardware I'm aware of focused on training, although there are rumors Nervana Systems may produce something [1]. I'm sure there are others; accelerating training of DNN isnt a particularly new idea.

The goal of these other computing architectures is typically\nto provide lower power, higher frequency/lower latency, or smaller form factor execution of trained models, but there is a question of how much value they can provide over more conventional chips to be worth the chip design costs.

However without these architectures becoming as mainstream as say a GPU, I think we will continue to see advances come from the typical everyday computer. The ML community seems to be much more democratic than others.

[0] http://googleresearch.blogspot.com/2015/12/when-can-quantum-...

[1] http://www.nervanasys.com/about/

Author: zAy0LfpBZLC8mAC
Content:
[... pt3 ...]

> One of the things I believe about God is that he knows everything about us,

How do you know that?

> and as such would be the most qualified to prescribe the best courses of action for my life and for society.

Even under that assumption, I would disagree.

> Or, since we're on HN, the guy who programmed the app knows the codebase better than anyone,

How do you know who that guy is?

> and if he wants others to understand it he writes documentation for others to follow,

How do you identify the author of that documentation?

> or maybe goes to a conference to talk about it.

How do you identify the speaker?

> And who knows, maybe God has reasoning that would fit within the realm of scientific methodology.

Sure, or maybe god likes pizza. May be. Or may not be. Speculation is easy. What's your evidence one way or the other?

> I don't know, but..."it's faith!"

Is there any claim that you couldn't justify that way?

"God wants me to only eat noodles! It's faith!"

"The core of jupiter consists of cheese! It's faith!"

"God wants me to love everyone! It's faith!"

"God wants me to kill all ! It's faith!"

How do you distinguish where "It's faith!" is sufficient justification and where it is not?

Now, this has become somewhat (ahem) lengthy, and most of these arguments aren't really new--if you are interested in understanding the skeptical/scientific/atheistic view on those things, you might enjoy this playlist:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOkwq0YkXJA&list=PL8U_Qmq9oN...

In particular, there are quite a few videos in there that deal with common theistic arguments, including "Appeals to Faith", "Morality", "Supernatural Causation", "Appeals to Personal Experience", which would probably roughly cover this post.

Author: zAy0LfpBZLC8mAC
Content:
[... pt2 ...]

> But ultimately, the chair can either hold you or it can't. One of those outcomes is true. Just because you can't sit on the chair doesn't mean that there isn't an absolute answer. I think you understand that after parsing your response a bit more, just wanted to call the point out specifically.

Yes, there is an absolute answer. But if you don't know it, you don't get to make one up and to then claim it's the truth, you simply don't know it, and that's it, until you do actually know it, for example by sitting down on the chair.

>> However, it is important to note that science does not proclaim that if you can't observe something, it therefore isn't. > > Yes! I understand this. But I do think that because science is so great at explaining so many things, people will tend to mentally fall into assumptions like 'science is the only way to prove something' or 'if science cannot prove something, I won't believe it'. This could be strawmanning though.

First of all, I want to draw a distinction: Science doesn't _prove_ anything, at all. Proof is the business of mathematics, and a proof only shows what follows logically from a given set of assumptions (called axioms by mathematicians), which doesn't say much about reality, as the assumptions are just assumptions, which might apply in reality, or they might not, mathematics doesn't care whether they do, it only shows what follows if you assume them to be true.

Science only deals with evidence, and it works by falsification, not by verification, let alone by proof. Science works by suggesting hypotheses and then trying to disprove them as hard as possible. Hypotheses that survive those attempts to disprove them for long enough are considered tentatively reliable knowledge, aka theories, not proven facts, as it is always assumed that future tries to disprove some theory might still succeed.

Now, yes, I won't believe something that science hasn't demonstrated (that is: hasn't tried reasonably hard to disprove). However, you have to be careful to not understand "science" as "by people in labcoats" here. Any method that has been demonstrated to provide reliable knowledge is scientific. If you could show that personal revelation is a path to reliable knowledge, I would count personal revelation as scientific evidence, and thus believe personal revelations. I don't dogmatically exclude any method of obtaining knowledge--all I ask for is that you demonstrate that it actually works, at which point it both becomes scientific and I will believe it. As long as I don't have anything beyond your claim that your method works, I won't believe what you say. "Unscientific" really is just a synonym for "hasn't been demonstrated to provide reliable knowledge"--and I would think it's obvious that you can't justify a claim with a method of which it is unknown whether it works.

> If I understand you correctly you're saying that, from a purely scientific standpoint, a belief in the Abrahamic God is no different than believing that we're a little simulation run by the Q Continuum. And that's a fair point.

What I am saying is that there is as much evidence for one as for the other, hence, there is no justification for believing one more or less than the other.

> But I would contend again that science is not the only way to prove something. Historical record, internal logic and narrative, testimony of others, personal experience, revelation...these can be less easy to parse and trust than a clear-cut scientific method, but that doesn't invalidate them as methods of persuasion.

Historical records are quite easy to observe, actually. But you don't get to just claim what they say, and that what they say is true. You have to demonstrate both the actual content of the actual records and that they are reliable, if you want me to believe something you supposedly found out about history. BTW, there isn't really all that much difference between historical records and any other kind of observation/measurement: The light from the screen that you are reading this on takes time to travel to your eyes, so what you see is also just a sort of historical record of the screen's content about a nanosecond earlier, just as much of the knowledge about the early development of our universe has been obtained by looking at light that has been traveling through the universe for billions of years, much of it from galaxies that probably don't even exist anymore. If you can observe it, you can use it as scientific evidence.

(Internal) logic is a somewhat difficult case, but then again it is actually not that much of a problem: It's philosophically difficult to pin down the "source of logic" (not that I'm saying that there is such a thing), but in practice, you won't find many people who will disagree with you about the most basic laws of logic, so there isn't really much need to justify them. Though it should be noted that you can empirically observe that they work, that is, if you use them, you are more successfull at navigating the world than if you don't.

Narrative is probably a source of hypotheses to test at best, testimony of other is perfectly fine scientific evidence, of course--however, the observation of the testimony is not to be confused with the observation of what the testimony is about. In order to use the former to judge the latter, you also need observations about the reliability of the testimony. Note that we know most of our (scientific) knowledge only "through testimony"--but what is important is that you in principle can go and repeat any of the experiments or observations that that testimony supposedly was based on to see whether it holds up. Personal experience is, if you will, the primary source of scientific knowledge--however, we also have figured out that it is extremely unreliable on its own, which is why science has developed elaborate methodology to avoid all the biases, confusions, and deceptions that individual personal experience tends to come with. As for revelation, see above.

But no, ultimately, there are no other ways to obtain reliable knowledge than by using methods that have been demonstrated to result in reliable knowledge, aka science.

> And perhaps that is our greatest difference. You (if I am understanding correctly; feel free to correct me) believe that belief should be withheld on things that cannot be quantified with scientific methodology. I do not ascribe to this, and this divergence puts us in pretty different places.

I would disagree on the wording. "quantified with scientific methodology" sounds too much like "by people in labcoats", and that's besides the point. Belief should be withheld until you can show that it aligns with reality.

>>>> what is moral is a scientific question >> I can see how you could start with that assumption and find ways to justify it, but I don't see how you can conclusively prove the initial premise. > I think the more interesting question is: Do you disagree and if so, why? > > If I understand the intent of this exchange, then I think I do disagree. Take something like eugenics; if we observed two societies doing it and one refraining, we might find benefits in both society. An individualistic society might be glad they refrained because they see the intrinsic value of each human life, regardless of their shortcomings, while a collectivistic, Spartan-like society might be glad they kept their stock strong and didn't have to do stuff like buy glasses or spend money on sick/disabled people. Point being, observation and the conclusions that are drawn from it could end up being inconclusive or relativistic depending on the underlying values of the society.

Well, sure we might find benefits in both societies, but which of the two do you think would be nicer to live in, all things considered?

Also, yes, observations could end up inconclusive, so you might have to make an arbitrary decision as to how to live. How does just making up an answer from the start and skipping the observation make things any less arbitrary than that worst case?

And do you have any evidence that morals do not depend on the underlying values of societies? That you wish they weren't doesn't make it so.

[...]

Author: zAy0LfpBZLC8mAC
Content:
> Thanks for taking the time to reply and speaking civilly! I've really come to enjoy discussions on Hacker News more than anywhere else.

:-)

>> I am speaking of observation, not revelation.\n> \n> Me too. There were lot of observations about people and events in first-century Palestine that were then recorded and preserved over time.

Sure, and based on that evidence I agree with you that there were humans living in first-century Palestine, for example.

> I was just in a meeting today. Let's say I write a blog post about it and that post is read 2000 years later. While it can't be the sole basis for answering the question of whether or not that meeting happened, I think it should be given a lot of respect and precedence when considering the question.

Well, that very much depends.

If the claim simply was that there was some meeting today in some company and that your were in it, and whether I believe it or not was essentially inconsequential, sure, might well have happened, that doesn't contradict anything I know about this world, there are meetings in companies all the time, and I assume that will still be a well-established fact 2000 years from now.

Now, if you asked me to bet my house on the truth of the claim that that meeting actually happened? No way I'd do that just based on a simple blog posting, even today, blog postings are just way too easy to fake.

Or if you claimed that in that meeting someone demonstrated that energy conservation doesn't hold, or that the speed of light can be exceeded, or that you resurrected a dead human ... no, your blog post wouldn't count for much as far as those claims are concerned, if anything at all, we have pretty solid evidence that energy is conserved, that the speed of light cannot be exceeded, and that rotting human bodies cannot be resurrected, at least with current medical technology. Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.

> But don't discount revelation outright! If I want someone to understand me better, I'd rather tell them myself rather than having them resort to observations and experiments, and I'd probably give them more information in an hour of talking than they ever could figure out on their own.

But first of all, listening to someone speak is perfectly fine observation, there is nothing supernatural about humans producing sound waves in patterns of some spoken language and other humans detecting/observing those sound waves, and secondly, if you said to me "I know everything", the observation I make is that you said "I know everything", not that you actually know everything, those two are two very distinct claims that would require very different evidence. Also, usually, if you talk to someone, you usually aren't limited to just listening and watching, you can even do interactive experiments, such as ask a question and then observe the reaction of the other person. That's how you usually figure out other people.

All of that demonstrably can provide reliable knowledge about the world. In contrast to the "having an experience", personal/internal type of revelation, which has an abysmal track record. Note though that I don't "discount [it] outright"--if you claim that that can provide reliable knowledge about the world, sure, possibly, but don't expect me to believe that until you have demonstrated it. I don't hold much hope for it though, given how contradictory claims are that people have made, supposedly based on such revelations, both versus one another and when compared to other (demonstrably reliable) methods of observation.

> If you can explain it completely, it's not faith. So that makes sense.

There is no such thing as "explain it completely". There is "you can explain it", aka "you know it", and there is "you can't explain it", aka "you don't know it". But there is no such thing as "completeness" in explanations. In a sense, there is no such thing as an explanation. There are models of reality, which colloquially are called explanations, but they are nothing more than descriptions of regularities that have been observed, and in every(!) model there are details of which we don't know whether more details couldn't possibly be found out at a later time. Why do we have day and night? Because the earth is spinning! Why is the earth spinning? Because it got angular momentum from the accretion disc around the sun that it formed in, and angular momentum is conserved! Why is angular momentum conserved? ... ad infinitum, or rather, until you get to the point where we don't know (yet), which is the point where the responsible thing to say is "I don't know", not ", because I have faith", because only "I don't know" logically leads to you possibly finding out, if you pretend you know even though you don't, chances are, you won't.

> The concept of a triune God is one that kinda ends up this way. I can pontificate all I want about how I'm a father, a son, and a brother all while being a single entity, but at the end of the day it's like explaining depth to Flatlanders - it's tough to truly understand something that doesn't exist on your level. So, what goes beyond my comprehension requires faith.

No, what goes beyond your comprehension, you don't comprehend, and chances are it's bullshit. If you can't comprehend something, you can't determine whether it's true, so, while it's quite possible that it is in fact true, it's just as possible that it's false, and without you being able to determine which of the two is the case by means of comprehension, just believing something "on faith" becomes a random game of chance, on some things you will be right, on others you will be wrong.

Humanity has heaps of experience with this method of obtaining supposed knowledge, by the way. People over time have believed all kinds of crazy shit "on faith"--that is to say: Stuff that we meanwhile have a working understanding of, much of which turned out to be wildly different from what people had sincerely held beliefs about "on faith". Luckily, some people avoided believing this supposed knowledge, so we now know, to pick a random example, about bacteria. People were perfectly convinced that demons were real, and they even developed "demon therapy" ... but as you might know, exorcism didn't quite do the trick, antibiotics did.

> Can it be used as a cop-out or an intellectually lazy answer? Sure! The Bible even suggests that faith is hard - a man once said to Jesus "I believe; help my unbelief!" But that doesn't mean it's not a valid state of mind.

No, that doesn't mean it's not a valid state of mind. But it also doesn't mean that it _is_ a valid state of mind. If you claim that it's a method to obtain reliable knowledge about the world, it's up to you to provide the evidence, it's not up to me to disprove any random evidence-free claim you make.

> I like the chair metaphor for this sort of talk. Sitting in a chair requires a measure of faith that it'll hold my weight. If I'm sitting in the chair, the question is already answered so no more faith is required (unless I wanted to question the idea that the chair would continue to hold my weight!).

None of this requires any faith, if you want to figure out whether a chair will hold your weight, you(!) use evidence. Does it look like chairs that you have experience holding your weight (it's the same model you have at home, maybe)? Does it look like chairs that you have experience not holding your weight (those rusty legs full of holes look just like that laundry rack of yours that fell apart yesterday, say)? Have you seen someone else sit on it? Does it stand in some context where there is an increased chance that it won't hold you (a room in your company where meetings are being held all the time vs. a long-forgotten corner in the attic)? All of those checks and many more are how you(!) decide whether you will sit down on a chair or not, or whether you maybe carefully test whether it will hold you before you sit down. You don't just sit down on any chair in the faith that it will hold you, and there very much are circumstances where you will refrain from sitting down based on the evidence you observe and your experience from previous observations as to what attributes tend to indicate a reliable chair and which indicate an unreliable chair. And still, you could be wrong, in which case you'll figure it out by trying to sit down, not by postulating some truth "on faith".

> If I couldn't sit in the chair because it's behind a glass wall in a museum, then I can choose to believe it will/won't hold me or I can choose to not make a decision because, who cares? And for a chair that's okay, because it's not being prescriptive or dealing with anything existential.

You can't choose belief. Belief is about whether you are convinced of the truth of some claim. Either you are convinced, or you are not. You cannot decide what you are convinced of. If you could decide your beliefs, you could decide, for example, to be convinced that jumping from a tall building is not dangerous. Once you believed that, you would jump out of the window of a skyscraper without any hesitation, just like you don't hesitate when stepping out of the door at ground level because you believe that to not be dangerous. Could you do that?

I for one would probably withhold belief. Just as above, if it looks reasonably solid (aka reasonably similar to chairs that I have experience holding my weight and reasonably dissimilar from chairs I have experience not holding my weight), I might tend to believe it. But if you asked me to bet my house on it, I probably would refuse.

[...]

Author: danharaj
Content:
> Your syllogism equivocates on the concept "observation" and does not follow.

I was going more for an analogy than an equality. I also did not mean to imply that the relevant moral observations are how one derives moral principles. The relevant observations are the questions: "I perceive situation X in reality. Is injustice present? Who has been aggrieved, and is there an aggressor?"

These are clearly observer dependent.

> Moral discussions are not a "game" since lives and, ultimately, civilization hangs in the balance

I vacillated on using the word game. The game isn't morality, but pondering what morality is. If I had called it a thought exercise I think it would have had slightly better connotations. I call processes of cognition games perhaps too often.

With respect to objectivity: Not even scientists attempt to achieve objectivity. They merely attempt to reach consensus. It can be a bitter and contentious process in even the most quantified sciences. For example, the disagreement over whether tetraquarks exist [1]. Objectivity is a naive concept. You cannot prove that your perception of objectivity is, well, objective. Objectivity is at best a useful fiction. It's actually a very useful fiction! But it can fail because one's understanding of objectivity cannot verify that it is objective.

I think you can imagine a kind of person who claims that others lack objectivity when they are disagreed with. They exist everywhere. There's a named logical fallacy for this kind of behavior. Demanding one's morality be objective does not make one's morality objective, but it means that every moral judgment one makes is now self-judged to be objective. The moral framework can be internally consistent but inconsistent in its reification into material judgments and actions.

> Moreover, your position assumes two things that the radical Islamists do not share; the value of a human life (in the here-and-now not some fantasy world) and that reason, not guns, are the means for resolving disagreements among civilized men.

Ok, so we're talking about "radical Islamists" now, so I'll assume you mean Daesh because the vague "radical Islam" is just a snarl phrase. Is Saudi Arabia an example of radical Islam? They're an ally to the United States. Notice how the countries that claim "reason, not guns, are the means for resolving disagreements" quite willingly and openly and readily act in direct contradiction of those ideals. There is a discrepancy between what people say morality is and what they do. Everyone loves their morality when it permits them to dominate others and shape the world the way they see fit. Everyone's morality permits them to commit atrocities.

I am a moral realist. I merely make the claim that a person should not believe they have a direct apprehension of moral truth because such a belief compromises the ability to apprehend moral truth. Therefore I demand of a person's moral framework that it be oriented towards analyzing and understanding differences between people's moral judgments. If I assume I am capable of understanding moral reality and meet someone who disagrees with me, I can either conclude they are incapable of the same understanding or the disagreement stems from different vantage points.

Believing two moral individuals can come up with different moral judgments in the same situation is the only sensible starting point towards reconciling conflicts. Understanding why moral people can come to different moral conclusions is the fundamental mechanism of justice. Otherwise violently asserting one's moral truth is the only mechanism.

> How do you deal with someone who not only doesn't share your moral "sentiments" but wants to actually kill you? Is there some basis to compromise in this case? Why do we shoot lions and bears instead of trying to reason with them? Is it moral for you to kill a fly in your house? What if I disagree and claim all life is sacred and you have a moral duty to leave the bugs alone and I am willing to use my guns to protect them from you? On what grounds could you possible oppose someone like that if you really believe morality is relative (i.e. subjective)?

I think you're missing the point. Just because science is supposed to be done via reproducing experiments and corroborating results between different scientists doesn't mean that science is paralyzed by the existence of a person who believes in crank theories and cannot properly run experiments and thus cannot effectively communicate their scientific activities to other scientists. Likewise my morality isn't paralyzed by hypothetical bug-zealots who act maximally unreasonably. If you believe the world is filled to the brim with brutish idiots with whom you cannot possibly communicate moral sentiments, well, I'll have you know there are plenty of them that feel exactly the same about you. How are you different? Your internal moral framework is no proof to me that you have a correct moral understanding of anything.

Here's a better example: You come across two kids at a playground. One sticks their tongue out at the other who then throws a punch and starts a fight.

30 seconds earlier, I saw the kid sticking their tongue out shove that other kid to the ground. Then I saw exactly what you saw.

I'm pretty sure our moral judgments are going to be different.

The real world is vastly more complicated than this contrived example. When you come into moral conflict with other people you can either assume they're a bunch of illogical, fact-spurning hate machines like the top-level comment in this thread[2], or you can believe that your difference in values and moral judgment of a situation arise from a difference in context which can be reconciled through communication and deliberation. If humans can't practically know everything in order to come to an absolute moral judgment, human morality is functionally observer dependent. That doesn't mean there isn't a moral reality that doesn't care about the vagaries of human perception and social context, it's just not practically accessible.

[1] https://www.quantamagazine.org/20140827-quark-quartet-fuels-...\n[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illusion_of_asymmetric_insight

Author: tomjakubowski
Content:
> Feinstein the hypocrite. She has a conceal carry permit yet many in CA are unable to get such.

This caught my attention (I love to catch a hypocrite), but I don't think it's actually true today.

Various sources indicate she did have a concealed carry permit, due to threats she received from the New World Liberation Front, but that she ditched the revolver she was carrying in her purse, thanks to the permit, at some point in the past (likely in 1982). Here's an article from left-wing biased source MediaMatters, which cites a 1982 WaPo article I couldn't verify (no LexisNexis access):

http://mediamatters.org/blog/2013/03/19/hannity-falsely-accu...

If you prefer sources from the other side, here's notorious right-wing blogger and floor-shitter Chuck C. Johnson reporting the same (with an entirely different spin):

http://dailycaller.com/2013/03/15/in-feinsteins-harvey-milk-...

And here's a post from TheHill, whose political bias (if any) I don't know:

http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/273989-fein...

TheHill's post doesn't mention a date, though.

Author: mirimir
Content:
> People are still sore about that. I have friends who remember hiding from NATO bombs.

"Death From Above" in Party Animals (2005) by Turbonegro.

Author: Strilanc
Content:
> They seem very conservative in their claims.

Hahaha!

D-Wave's reputation is one of exaggeration and putting marketing before science. That's how Scott ended up as de-facto "chief D-Wave skeptic": he kept complaining about their exaggerations and the exaggerations of journalists covering them.

(The paper being discussed now does actually seem conservative in its claims, but it's by a team at Google; not D-Wave.)

Author: untog
Content:
What stops them from offering an option to get files as well?

Well, they don't want you to be able to permanently download the files. If you cancel your subscription you'll lose whatever you have downloaded. Offering you a file you can easily convert into a different format would break that pretty comprehensively.
